text: I really found this critique of Coates' "Between the World and Me" thought-provoking: <https://www.viewpointmag.com/2017/05/17/the-birthmark-of-damnation-ta-nehisi-coates-and-the-black-body/> -- the author talks more about it in this week's Chapo: <https://soundcloud.com/chapo-trap-house/episode-113-hit-and-run-feat-rl-stephens-53117>

attachments.title: The Birthmark of Damnation: Ta-Nehisi Coates and the Black Body
attachments.text: Coates’s descriptive language and haunting narrative are not mere metaphors. They act as an ontological pivot, mystifing racism even as it is anchored in its physical effects.
attachments.fallback: Viewpoint Magazine: The Birthmark of Damnation: Ta-Nehisi Coates and the Black Body

attachments.title: Episode 113 - Hit and Run feat. R.L. Stephens (5/31/17) by Chapo Trap House
attachments.text:
NOTE: Due to overwhelming public demand, we made this premium episode free.

Our pal, writer and organizer R.L. Stephens is with us talking about the limits of liberal anti-racism, his critique of Ta-Nehisi Coates, organizing, pessimism, and why materialism matters.

Here's R.L.'s new piece:
